SourcedStatement: One day last fall, Bryant Woods’ rotted-out flooring opened up beneath his 11-year-old daughter.
Name: Bryant Woods

SourcedStatement: Major leaks in the rental home had allowed mold to thrive and rot to set in.
Name: Bryant Woods

SourcedStatement: In the winters, he was forced to use space heaters or his electric oven to stay warm since the heat didn’t work.
Name: Bryant Woods

SourcedStatement: For years, Woods’ relationship with his longtime landlord has been deteriorating.
Name: Bryant Woods

SourcedStatement: About nine months ago, the two men agreed he could withhold rent until repairs were made, he said.
Name: Bryant Woods

SourcedStatement: In the meantime, he started looking for a new place to live.
Name: Bryant Woods

SourcedStatement: But, his landlord’s unwillingness to cooperate with rental history checks by property management firms made finding a new home for his family of five extremely difficult.
Name: Bryant Woods

SourcedStatement: Then, recently, his landlord caught him by surprise and filed for eviction.
Name: Bryant Woods

SourcedStatement: He couldn’t prove his missed rent payments were part of a verbal agreement, so the judge granted the property owner’s request and told Woods his family had 10 days to move.
Name: Bryant Woods

SourcedStatement: He left the courthouse without much hope.
Name: Bryant Woods

SourcedStatement: To reduce such evictions, one of the court’s judges, Deborah Henderson; Shelby County Commissioner Erika Sugarmon; and Cindy Ettingoff, then-CEO of Memphis Area Legal Services, last summer secured $240,000 in the county budget to pilot a pre-litigation mediation program for landlord-tenant disputes.
Name: Deborah Henderson
Title: Judge

SourcedStatement: The cash didn’t make it to MALS until February 2024, due to problems with how the County Commission resolution was originally drafted, Henderson said.
Name: Deborah Henderson
Title: Judge

SourcedStatement: But Henderson has been happy with the results since then.
Name: Deborah Henderson
Title: Judge

SourcedStatement: Recently, MALS worked with a woman who was living in a house that “should not be lived in by anyone” and was starting to fall behind on rent, Henderson said.
Name: Deborah Henderson
Title: Judge

SourcedStatement: It seemed like a case headed toward an eviction for the tenant, a code violation for the landlord or both.
Name: Deborah Henderson
Title: Judge

SourcedStatement: But with MALS’ help, the landlord is making repairs, and the tenant is using some leftover rental assistance funds to catch up on rent.
Name: Deborah Henderson
Title: Judge

SourcedStatement: Though the program has only helped a couple of tenants so far — not 300 — Henderson believes it’s already proving its value.
Name: Deborah Henderson
Title: Judge

SourcedStatement: To drum up more business, Henderson and MALS attorney Cedric Harris, who is leading the program, have been spending a few nights and weekends this summer speaking to churches, on radio shows and at other events.
Name: Deborah Henderson
Title: Judge

SourcedStatement: “There are no income limits or income requirements,” Henderson told a WLOK-AM audience earlier this summer.
Name: Deborah Henderson
Title: Judge

SourcedStatement: “If you’re a tenant who is having trouble with your landlord, you need to give us a call.
Name: Deborah Henderson
Title: Judge

SourcedStatement: … If you’re a landlord and you have a troublesome tenant … give us a call.”
Name: Deborah Henderson
Title: Judge

SourcedStatement: Nicole Grida, the new MALS CEO, said her team has started creating marketing materials for the program, building partnerships with local nonprofits and screening folks who call in for other services to see if they will fit the program’s criteria, which has resulted in many promising leads.
Name: Nicole Grida
Title: CEO, MALS

SourcedStatement: For the program to succeed, Grida said raising greater awareness will be key, as most Memphians it could help don’t yet know it exists.
